Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Sequential Predictors for Partial Differential Equation and Delay Systems: Designs, Theory, and Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project solves the problem of implementability of feedback controls for a variety of dynamical systems that arise in additive manufacturing, battery modeling, deep mine elevators, oil drilling, traffic congestion, water desalination, and other engineering domains. Feedback control involves the use of information about the states of dynamical systems and about their surroundings, to decide how to adjust the behavior of the systems to realize important objectives such as ensuring that the systems safely converge to a desirable operating mode with minimal human intervention. The project combines the PIs' complementary expertise in engineering and mathematics, by tackling important interdisciplinary problems that could not be solved outside of this new collaborative framework. The project studies interconnected systems with delays, in which the current states of the systems or of their surroundings may not be available for use in the feedback control design, and related problems in extremum seeking under delays, in which one wishes to minimize important types of cost criteria. Through the PIs' contacts with engineers from industry, the project will increase the engineering community's use of more rigorous methods to obtain better performing controls and will also provide interdisciplinary training to graduate students that is guided by compelling engineering applications.

The project provides transformative control and extremum seeking algorithms for key classes of ODE and ODE-PDE cascades that involve delays, prescribed regulation times, and uncertainties. Input delays arise from sensor or transport phenomena, and finite time constraints occur when there are hard deadlines for achieving control objectives. While prediction has been used extensively, there are currently no analogs of prediction for stabilization problems with prescribed regulation times where there are delays and uncertain model parameters. This project overcomes these challenges for general classes of nonlinear systems, using new sequential predictors, sequential anti-diffusors, chain observers, adaptive control with parameter identification, and extremum seeking under delays or time constraints, including cases where only sampled output measurements are available. The controls developed ensure better disturbance rejection and robustness against uncertainties. The project is guided by cutting edge engineering applications, to ensure the usefulness of the theory. They involve models for underwater marine robots where slow acoustic communication is modeled through long delays, the reduction of severe slugging in oil production, and online social networks where opinion spreading is modeled by PDE-ODE cascades with diffusion. The project will include experimental real time implementation of some of the controls and train PhD students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mathematical models of traffic, undersea construction, oil drilling, Lithium-ion batteries, additive manufacturing, and other technological and even social systems are dominated by time delays and spatially-distributed dynamics modeled by partial differential equations. While advances of the last two decades have laid the foundation for control of such systems, the real technological usefulness requires that such algorithms be developed for more complex configurations of interconnections of such systems and that the control designs be equipped with learning capabilities in order to handle the model uncertainties. 

 

With over 60 papers in leading journals, and two research monographs, the present project has furnished breakthroughs on five distinct fronts in this challenging field. 

 

The first thrust was control of PDEs (partial differential equations) interconnected with other ODEs (ordinary differential equations) and other PDEs. Such system structures are motivated by physics and engineering applications. Control algorithms with a full measurement of the state, estimators of the unmeasured state, and combinations of such controllers and observers into output-feedback laws have been developed for ODE-PDE-ODE and PDE-ODE-PDE sandwich configurations, ensuring stabilization of such systems, in some case using sampled-data measurement. Several of the results achieved in the project are for stabilization of stop-and-go oscillations in congested traffic. The project has provided feedback laws that achieve stabilization of traffic oscillations upstream of a ramp using ramp metering, i.e., using modulation of the length of the red and green lights on a ramp in response to the fluctuations in the density and velocity traffic profiles upstream of the same ramp. 

 

The second thrust has been on “predictor feedback,” namely, the compensation of delays at the actuator or at the sensor of a control system. Nonlinear dependencies of the delays and transport models have been enabled. Particularly important results on this project are the generalized Halanay inequalities, with which the PIs have enabled less restrictive designs of observers and controllers for time-varying systems and with sampled-data architectures. 

 

The third thrust of the project has produced a large number of results for ADAPTIVE control of delay systems and PDEs. These results provide a comprehensive set of design tools where the system may suffer from one or more of the following uncertainties: unknown delay, unknown ODE parameters, unmeasured state of the ODE, unmeasured actuator state. The PI’s team has solved adaptive problems for both discrete delays and for distributed delays, and for both single-input and multi-input systems, with distinct delays. This comprehensive line of work has been crowned by publication of a new book, with Princeton University Press, on delay-adaptive control of linear systems. 

 

The fourth thrust of the project has generated extremum seeking algorithms in the presence of delays or other PDE dynamics at the input or the output of unknown static maps and unknown dynamical systems. Predictor feedback, which enables these breakthroughs, is seemingly inapplicable to extremum seeking because predictor feedback requires a model, whereas in extremum seeking the model is unknown. However, with an innovative use of perturbation signals, the PI’s team manages to estimate both the unknown gradients and Hessians and generate predictor-based compensation of the delay and PDE dynamics. One of the applications is for maximizing the flow through traffic bottlenecks, such as bottlenecks created by traffic accidents, which are typically some distance (possibly several miles) away from a ramp with which traffic is actuated. The PI’s algorithms seek, and find, the optimal rate of letting cars on a ramp onto the freeway to maximize the traffic flow past an accident site. 

 

The project’s fifth thrust solves a decade-old problem of quantifying the effect of boundary disturbances on PDE dynamics, such as ocean surface waves affecting the drilling dynamics downhole in offshore rigs. In PDEs with boundary disturbances, the input operator is unbounded, seemingly making ISS (input-to-state stability) impossible. The PI’s team not only proves that PDEs are ISS but also provide explicit gain estimates for PDEs. Moreover, they produce tools for small-gain analysis of stability, enabling feedback connections of multiple PDEs, even from distinct PDE classes, in all the relevant spatial and temporal norms. Upon laying the fundamentals to this research area through a series of papers, the PI and coauthor published a book on this subject with Springer, which received a glowing review in the leading journal, Automatica. 

 

The project has provided several PhD students with training and has launched their industrial or academic careers.
